text:
alright so I did straight markovian (random walk assumptions in place) prediction of `PriceCenter` -- have not computed f score.  Do have some good news and bad news.

• bad news: the way we were thinking about things is not going to work.  The closer you get to the event horizon, the less you can predict anything from where you are right now.  
• good news: there is a bit of a paradigm shift.  If we think in terms of an F-Score window approx 30-120 in the future, the ability to predict might be a lot better than we imagined. 
But, maybe insight into the event horizon will improve with some of the book data.

elements.text: alright so I did straight markovian (random walk assumptions in place) prediction of

-- have not computed f score.  Do have some good news and bad news.
bad news: the way we were thinking about things is not going to work.  The closer you get to the event horizon, the less you can predict anything from where you are right now.
good news: there is a bit of a paradigm shift.  If we think in terms of an F-Score window approx 30-120 in the future, the ability to predict might be a lot better than we imagined.
But, maybe insight into the event horizon will improve with some of the book data.

text: the big takeaway there is I am hitting >60% likelihood of correctly predicting whether the stock is going to be higher or lower 30-120 min from the event horizon.

elements.text: the big takeaway there is I am hitting >60% likelihood of correctly predicting whether the stock is going to be higher or lower 30-120 min from the event horizon.

text: the amount notwithstanding, what that means is when we have a robot doing inferences on the minute every minute for a sweep of say 30-120 minutes in the future, then we accumulate 90 predictions on every minute by the time we make a purchase decision.

text:
>  nuke the button press
basically, take 90 individual prediction opportunities applied to a single minute in the future as it marches towards the present by 3 different models (say, simple, medium and high complexity) can generate a total of 270 predictions for any given point in time.  By synthesizing these predictions to make that push-don't-push decision, we'd have nuked it; e.g. dedicated an asymmetric number of resources to a single position relative to what other people are doing, and we win.

elements.text: nuke the button press

basically, take 90 individual prediction opportunities applied to a single minute in the future as it marches towards the present by 3 different models (say, simple, medium and high complexity) can generate a total of 270 predictions for any given point in time.  By synthesizing these predictions to make that push-don't-push decision, we'd have nuked it; e.g. dedicated an asymmetric number of resources to a single position relative to what other people are doing, and we win.

text:
And so I can plan out how to generate a couple of categorically different predictors (predictors that rely on different technique and data) to beat the 50% mark.

• one more reason here: with the book data, I might be able to get closer to the Event Horizon w/ better than 50% odds the model predicts direction correctly.

elements.text: And so I can plan out how to generate a couple of categorically different predictors (predictors that rely on different technique and data) to beat the 50% mark.
one more reason here: with the book data, I might be able to get closer to the Event Horizon w/ better than 50% odds the model predicts direction correctly.

text:
After that, it would be down to setting up the "fusion" of predictions (not ensembling, but rather statistically fusing ML predictions with known variance and success rates for a superior result), and finally simulations and strategy: when we get good at predicting the future in some window or way, how does the bot make money with that information.
• from an ML perspective, the hard part will be, when this goes live, continually recalibrating the fusion and re-training
• e.g. the prediction system will have to continuously factor in how it is doing in real time (1 minute)
